Award.AwardTitle: Modern Aspects of Complex Analysis and Its Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the conference Modern Aspects of Complex Analysis and Its Applications, held at the University of Washington in Seattle, Washington, during August 19-23, 2019. The meeting aims to foster interaction between experts and early-career mathematicians working in the field of complex analysis. The structure of the conference will comprise a number of workshop-style talks directed at beginning researchers that are focused on presenting and discussing fundamental ideas in the field. The organizers are making an effort to attract younger and minority researchers to participate in the conference.

The field of complex analysis is a classical discipline at the root of much of modern mathematics. Over the years, its boundaries have been pushed in many different and often surprising directions: from random geometric objects, to fractal geometry and dynamics, to discrete networks and data science. The goal of the conference is to bring together researchers across generational cohorts in the field of complex analysis with various related areas, including random conformal maps, dynamical systems, and geometric function theory. Topics discussed will include harmonic analysis, geometric measure theory, quasiconformal maps, analysis on metric spaces, and probability. More information can be found at the meeting web site https://www.math.ksu.edu/~pietro/seattle19.html.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellctual Merit:

The grant supported the conference ``Modern Aspects of Complex Analysis and Its Applications" that took place at the Unversity of Seattle on August 19-23, 2019. The conference brought together a number of researchers across generational cohorts, and across various sub-fields of analysis, with an emphasis on complex analysis. Research in complex analysis in the past decades has brought advances on longstanding problems, but also the creation of new subﬁelds that have seen tremendous recent activity such as the stochastic Loewner evolution, fractal geometry, complex dynamics, or applications in network and data science. Through 26 invited plenary talks and poster sessions, leading US-based researchers and international experts reported on recent developments in their fields. The talks focused on fundamental ideas and were also accessible to more junior researchers.  Highlights included a talk by the president of the AMS Jill Pipher, as well as talks by Chris Bishop and by Yilin Wang on Weil-Petersson curves that exemplified the interplay of analysis, geometry and probability theory.

Broader impact:

The conference served as a bridge between the generations: the younger researchers got a better sense of what classical tools have been developed and what is available for their own pursuit of the latest trends, while the more senior researchers became inspired to apply their knowledge to some of questions in some of the new and rapidly developing subfields.
